comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: No, these are giant political posters, featuring anti-Tammany cartoon drawings. The Tammany tiger symbol was devised by the famous Harper's Weekly cartoonist Thomas Nast, who also invented the elephant and donkey symbols of the Republican and Democratic parties. The tiger in the foreground has the word "Tammany" on a collar around its neck. The posters appear to have suffered an assault by pro-Tammany hooligans.

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: Eric L. Boetzel, the man in the photograph, was a former deputy Attorney General of New York state, and a former Assistant District Attorney of NYC, who had resigned that office to become assistant manager of the 1913 New York City mayoralty campaign of John Purroy Mitchel, the fusion candidate, who won election.

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: LOC -- his name was BOETZEL, with a zed, not an ess. Bain at this period had a clerk on staff who was unable to inscribe a proper zee.

comment.author: 54904823@N00
comment._content: I started a Wikipedia entry for him: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eric_Louis_Boetzel

comment.author: 34997905@N03
comment._content: Wystan. Thanks. Will submit for correction to the catalog record.
